repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Karachi Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall outcome of the project is
            unsatisfactory, and sustainability is unlikely. Despite a
            modest institutional development impact, both performances
            by the Bank, and Borrower were unsatisfactory. Considering
            the current quality assurance standards, project preparation
            was deficient, with appraisal of works based only on
            preliminary engineering designs, with very narrow remedial
            action, particularly as it regards the underestimated
            project cost increase of approximately seventy three
            percent. Lessons show that the lack of a regulatory
            framework, hindered the possibilities for the Karachi Water
            and Sewerage Board (KWSB) to make full use of the support
            provided by the project in strengthening the institution.
            There was no regulatory action to give KWSB the autonomy to
            exercise changes, neither in private sector involvement,
            tariff adjustments, nor collection enforcement, changes
            which could have improved service quality, in addition to
            providing a sustainable management capacity, to offset
            continued leaks, and prevent inequalities in resource
            allocation. Furthermore, this lack of autonomy translates
            into the financial covenants' limitations to assure
            compliance, thus the usefulness of financial undertakings is
            questioned, in the absence of governance, and adverse
            commercial incentives, obstacles which could have ensured
            the adequacy of water supply.

Pakistan - Second Karachi Water Supply and

repnme.cdata!:
Pakistan - Second Karachi Water Supply and
            Sanitation Project (supplemental Credit)

abstracts.cdata!:
The primary objectives of the project
            are to : increase potable water supply, improve operation,
            management and financial viability of the Karachi Water and
            Sewerage Board (KWSB) and, improve sanitation in the city of
            Karachi. Specific project components include : (i) a canal
            and a square conduit to bring water from the Indus river,
            four pumping stations, two direct filtration treatment
            works, storage reservoirs, and the expansion/rehabilitation
            of the distribution network; (ii) three new sewage treatment
            works together with trunk sewers, cleaning of existing
            sewers and the provision of small bore sewers to low-income
            areas; and (iii) technical assistance to KWSB to enable it
            to plan and execute large scale projects, improve operation
            and maintenance, and improve and extend sanitation in the
            city and coastal areas. The objectives of the project are
            to: (a) increase potable water by 100 million gallons per
            day and further augment water availability strengthening
            loss reduction measures; (b) improve the financial avail of
            the Karachi Water and Sewerage Board (KWSB) through
            increased reven cost reductions, and increased operational
            efficiency; (c) improve the organization and management of
            KWSB; and (d) improve sanitation in Kar including its
            low-income and coastal areas. The project has three mai
            components: (a) water supply, including transmission works,
            pumping s direct filtration treatment works, storage
            reservoirs, distribution ma strengthening of the
            distribution network; (b) institutional strengthe KWSB; and
            (c) sanitation, including three sewage treatment works toget
            associated trunk sewers, repair and cleaning of existing
            sewers, and small-bore sewers for low income neighborhoods.
            The project will plac increased emphasis on leak detection
            and water loss reduction, contain operating costs, enhanced
            revenue mobilization efforts, and an in-dept examination of
            possible options for public/private sector participatio
            provision of water and sanitation services.
